items.title: You want to be in control of your own Copilot with Ty Dunn - founder of Continue.dev
items.author: probabl
items.content:
There are many LLMs that you can use for programming these days. Some of them even go into your IDE like Cursor or Github Copilot. But what if you want to tweak these LLMs do to what you want? Instead of being stuck with the tools that a vendor gives you, the goal of Continue.dev is to allow you to customise this yourself. In this podcast we talk to Ty Dunn, co-founder of the project to learn more about this.

If you are curious to learn more about this effort, please check out https://continue.dev. You may always want to read the manifesto over at https://amplified.dev/. 

00:00 Introduction
00:56 It starts at highschool
05:57 College
15:00 LLMs 
19:22 Founding Continue.dev
29:22 Making changes to VSCode
34:30 Many coding models
38:55 Overfitting on Python
46:11 The diff really matters
55:30 Learning with LLMs in the mix

We have a Discord these days, feel free to discuss the podcast with us there!
https://discord.probabl.ai

You can follow the podcast on most podcast players including apple podcasts, spotify and rss.com.

items.title: Building custom VSCode copilots with continue.dev
items.author: probabl
items.content:
There are a lot of vendors for LLMs out there that help you write code. But what if you want to carve out your own path and make a bespoke tool that really fits you? This week we are going to explore exactly this during our livestream by leveraging continue.dev. We may even make our own LLM to help us!

Website: https://probabl.ai/
Discord: https://discord.probabl.ai/
LinkedIn: https://www.linkedin.com/company/probabl

If you're keen to see more videos like this, you can follow us over at  @probabl_ai.

items.title: How the HashingVectorizer works
items.author: probabl
items.content:
You can use the CountVectorizer in scikit-learn to encode text to a sparse array that a machine learning model can use. This functionality is great, but it can result in *huge* widths. An alternative to this is the HashingVectorizer, which we discuss in this video.

The notebooks for the dirty category series can be found here:
https://github.com/probabl-ai/youtube-appendix/tree/main/15-dirtycat

items.title: Optuna: a hyperparameter optimization framework
items.author: probabl
items.content:
Scikit-learn allows you to perform hyperparameter search but a lot of it happens in memory. Sometimes you want to have a storage layer for these hyperparameters and that's where a project like Optuna might be helpful. We will explore it in this livestream and kick the tires a bit. 

Notebook link:
https://github.com/probabl-ai/youtube-appendix/blob/main/00-livestream/optuna.ipynb

items.title: Why the MinHashEncoder is great for boosted trees
items.author: probabl
items.content:
Boosted tree models don't support sparse matrices, which might make you think they have trouble encoding text data. There are, however, encoding techniques that can work great without resorting to sparse methods. The MinHash encoder is one such technique and this video explains why it is a great choice for many pipelines. 

00:00 Introduction 
01:03 Hashing text 
05:16 Plotting hashes
06:22 Code demo
09:46 Pipelines

items.title: Nixtla: tools for timeseries
items.author: probabl
items.content:
There is a suite of tools for timeseries from the Nixtla ecosystem. We won't be able to cover all the tools in here, but since a few tools play nice with the scikit-learn ecosystem we will go ahead and explore those. 

There is a potential bug that we may have found at the end of the livestream, which we report to Nixtla here https://github.com/Nixtla/mlforecast/issues/457

The notebook with all the code can be found over here:
https://github.com/probabl-ai/youtube-appendix/blob/main/00-livestream/nixtla-demo.ipynb

items.title: The optimisers curse
items.author: probabl
items.content:
When looking for the best hyperparameters you can spend a lot of compute. So much so, that you can also spend *too much*. It is a sutble thing, but if you're not careful you can become a victim to something that's known as "the optimisers curse". This video explains the warning in full detail.

items.title: Successive Halving
items.author: probabl
items.content:
There is an experimental technique for cross validation in scikit-learn that revolves around "Successive Halving". In this livestream we discuss how the technique works but also why the approach is still considered experimental at the time of making this recording.

items.title: Scikit-learn utilities made with Rust.
items.author: probabl
items.content:
Python can be slow, and Rust can make things go vroom! Or at least, that seems to be a general sentiment. In this livestream we will explore when and if it can make sense to add Rust to a toolchain. In particular we will explore speedups that might make sense for custom scikit-learn utilities. 

Website: https://probabl.ai/
